title-group.article-title: Input data for test cases used in benchmarking triaxial failure theories of composites

author-notes.corresp: AS Kaddour, QinetiQ, Farnborough, Hampshire GU14 0LX, UK Email: askaddour@QinetiQ.com

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Evaluation of Theories for Predicting Failure in Polymer Composite Laminates Under 3-D States of Stress: Part A of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II)

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This article gives details of the input data provided for use in the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II) for benchmarking triaxial failure criteria. It includes (a) three-dimensional elastic constants, ultimate strains and strengths and the nonlinear stress–strain curves for five unidirectional laminae and their constituents and (b) a description of 12 challenging test cases of 5 composite laminates, the lay-ups, layer thicknesses, stacking sequences and the loading conditions. The originators of 3D failure theories were requested to use the exact data provided here in their blind predictions of the test cases. The instructions issued to the contributors are also presented at the end of this article.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In a recent activity, known as the first World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE),1 the authors completed an important phase in benchmarking failure criteria for continuous fibre reinforced polymer composites when subjected to two-dimensional (2D) states of stress. It was concluded from that activity that the predictive capabilities of failure criteria for dealing with triaxial or 3D states of stresses remain largely unknown. To close this gap in our knowledge, the authors have launched a new international activity – the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II).2

In the WWFE-II, 12 groups representing well-known originators of 3D failure criteria were requested to run their models to make predictions for a set of challenging test cases. They were asked to use an agreed, common set of input data (material properties, geometry, lay-up, loading conditions, etc.) for all of these test cases. This article provides details of the input data given to and employed by the participants of the WWFE-II. Details of 12 models used and their predictions are published in various associated references.3–14 A comparison between all of these predictions is made in Kaddour and Hinton.15

sec.title: General considerations
sec.p: Many different types of composite materials are available and these include woven, nonwoven, braided, stitched, z-pin. To make the exercise manageable, consideration was limited to laminated continuous fibre-reinforced polymer composites. Taking into consideration the availability of suitably extensive experimental data for laminates, two important and widely used classes of fibres (anisotropic carbon and isotropic glass) and one class resin system (epoxy resins) were selected for the exercise.

A unidirectional (UD) lamina made of continuous fibres in a softer matrix is considered to be the basic building block for the multidirectional laminates. The properties of the laminate depend very much on the properties (especially the relative orientation) of the laminae. The behaviour of each lamina is, in turn, governed by its constituents, i.e. the properties of the fibres, the surrounding matrix, the interface and the relative amount of fibres and matrix in the lamina.

For performing a theoretical analysis of the mechanical behaviour of multidirectional laminates under various loadings, most theories require as input data the properties of each of the individual laminae that constitute the laminate. The properties required include: elastic constants and thermal properties, strengths, failure strains and in some cases, the full stress–strain curves. Some methods of analysis require property information of the constituent fibres and matrix.

The 3D elastic constants for an orthotropic UD lamina consist of the following independent in-plane and through-thickness properties:
– Longitudinal (along the fibre) modulus E1,
– Transverse (perpendicular to the fibre) modulus E2,
– Through-thickness (perpendicular to the fibre) modulus E3,
– In-plane shear modulus G12,
– Transverse shear modulus G13,
– Through-thickness shear modulus G23,
– Major in-plane Poisson’s ratio υ12,
– Transverse Poisson’s ratio υ13 and
Through-thickness Poisson’s ratio υ23 where the subscripts 1, 2 and 3 refer to the three mutually perpendicular principal material directions. Figures 1 and 2 show schematic diagrams of a UD lamina with the co-ordinate system used. Typically, the remaining Poisson’s ratios can be obtained by applying the reciprocal Maxwell relations, which give υij/Ei = υji/Ej. Four of these constants (E1, E2, υ12 and G12) pertain to the in-plane behaviour of thin laminae and the remainder relate to the through-thickness (direction 3) behaviour. Figure 1.
A schematic showing lamina coordinates: 1: fibre direction, 2: transverse direction, 3: through-thickness direction. Figure 2.
A schematic showing a positive fibre orientation angle (θ) in relation to the reference axes.

It is normally assumed that a unidirectional fibre-reinforced lamina can be treated as transversely isotropic. This assumption thereby reducing the number of independent elastic constants to five because E2 = E3, G12 = G13, υ12 = υ13 and G23 = E2/2(1 + υ23).

Orthotropic composites generally possess nine strengths and nine failure strain values. These are:
– longitudinal tensile and compressive properties (XT, ε1T, XC and ε1C)
– transverse tensile and compressive properties (YT, ε2T, YC and ε2C)
– through-thickness tensile and compressive properties (ZT, ε3T, ZC and ε3C)
– in-plane and through-thickness shear properties (S12, γ12u, S13, γ13u, S23 and γ23u).

sec.title: Material properties
sec.p:
Five types of fibres were selected in the analysis, two types of glass fibre and three types of carbon fibre. They were chosen for consistency with data for particular laminates. The fibres are:
– E-Glass fibres
– S2-Glass fibres,
– T300 carbon fibres
– AS carbon fibres
– IM7 carbon fibres

Five types of epoxy matrices were used in the analysis. These are:
– MY750
– Epoxy 1
– Epoxy 2
– PR-319
– 8551-7

Using the above matrices and fibres, five types of laminae were used and these are
E-Glass/MY750
S2-Glass/epoxy
AS carbon/epoxy
IM7/8551-7 carbon/epoxy
T300/PR319 carbon/epoxy

Tables 1 to 3 show typical data for the properties of five unidirectional laminae, five epoxy resin matrices and five types of glass or carbon fibres. It was noted in Table 1 that the stress–strain behaviour of some composite laminates is sometimes highly nonlinear, particularly in shear and under transverse compression. Figures 3 to 5 show typical stress–strain curves for the selected laminae and the matrices under a variety of uniaxial loadings. Data from these figures are also presented in tabular form in Tables 4 to 6 for the UD laminae. All fibres were assumed to behave in a linear elastic manner up to failure. Figure 3.
In-plane shear stress–strain curve for the various unidirectional materials. Figure 4.
Transverse compressive stress–strain curves for the various unidirectional materials. Figure 5.
Tensile, compressive and shear stress–strain curves for 3 epoxy materials. Table 1.

sec.title: Details of the test cases
sec.p:
Twelve test cases were selected for the benchmark study in WWFE-II. The test cases have been chosen carefully to stretch each theory to the full and thereby shed light on their strengths and weaknesses. They are focused on a range of classical, continuous fibre, laminated, reinforced polymer composites subjected, in the absence of stress concentrations, to a variety of triaxial loading conditions. The key issues being explored are:
– The means by which the theories distinguish (if at all) between the effects of anisotropy and heterogeneity.
– The types of failure mechanism employed and the way that each is implemented within any given theory.
– The accuracy and bounds of applicability of each theory

Table 9 summarises laminate type, material type and the graphical results requested. Five different lay-ups were chosen in the exercise and these are
A base resin with isotropic properties,
0° unidirectional lamina,
Quasi-isotropic (0°/±45°/90°)s laminate,
Angle-ply (±35°)s laminate and
Cross-ply (0°/90°)s laminate.
Table 9.
Details of the test cases
Test case Laminate lay-up Material Description of required prediction
1 Resin MY750 epoxy σx versus σz (with σy = σz) envelope
2 0° T300/PR319 τ12 versus σ2 (with σ1 = σ2 = σ3) envelope
3 0° T300/PR319 γ12 versus σ2 (with σ1 = σ2 = σ3) envelope
4 0° T300/PR319 Shear stress–strain curves (τ12 – γ12) (for σ1 = σ2 = σ3 = −600 MPa)a

6 0° S-glass/epoxy σ1 versus σ3 (with σ2 = σ3) envelope
7 0° A-S carbon/epoxy σ1 versus σ3 (with σ2 = σ3) envelope
8 ±35° E-glass/MY750 epoxy σy versus σz (with σx = σz) envelope
9 ±35° E-glass/MY750 epoxy Stress–strain curves (σy – εx and σy – εy) at σz = σx = −100 MPab

11 (0°/90°)s IM7/8551-7 τyz versus σz (with σy = σx = 0) envelope
12 (0°/90°)s IM7/8551-7 Stress–strain curves (σz – εz, σz – εx and σz – εy) for σy = σx = 0

The loadings include the following:
Nine failure envelopes under the following combinations of stresses
– σx, versus σy (with σy = σz) for test case 1
– τ12 versus σ1 (with σ1 = σ2 = σ3) for test case 2
– γ12 versus σ1 (with σ1 = σ2 = σ3) for test case 3
– σ2 versus σ1 (with σ1 = σ3) for test case 5
– σ1 versus σ2 (with σ2 = σ3) for test cases 6 and 7
– σy versus σz (with σx = σz) for test case 8
– τzy versus σz (with σx = σy = 0) for test cases 10 and 11
Three stress–strain curves described as follows:
– Shear stress–strain curves (τ12 versus γ12 curves) under σ1 = σ2 = σ3 = −600 MPa, for test case 4.
– σy versus εy and σy versus εx for σx = σy = σz = −100 MPa followed by σx = σz = −100 MPa, for test case 9.
– Compressive through-thickness stress–strain curves σz versus εz (and εy and εx) for σx = σy = 0, for test case 12.

The instructions to participants (Appendix 1) specify how loads were to be applied and how results were to be presented. In some cases, failure envelopes are requested and Figure 6 shows a diagrammatic representation of a failure envelope where various stages of failure could take place before final failure. Figure 6.
Schematic of a failure envelope where initial and final failure stages are marked. Figure 7.
Recommended scales for plotting the theoretical prediction for test case 1. Variation of the compressive strength (σx) of polymeric resin matrix with stress σy( = σz). Figure 8.
Recommended scales for plotting the theoretical prediction for test case 2. Variation of shear strength (τ12) with stress σ2( = σ1 = σ3) for a unidirectional carbon/epoxy. Figure 9.
Recommended scales for plotting the theoretical prediction for test case 3. Variation of shear failure strain (γ12) with stress σ2(=σ1 = σ3) for a unidirectional carbon/epoxy. Figure 10.
Recommended scales for plotting the theoretical prediction for test case 4. Test case 1: Shear stress–strain curve (τ12 versus γ12) for a unidirectional carbon/epoxy for σ1 = σ2 = σ3 = 600 MPa. Figure 11.
Recommended scales for plotting the theoretical prediction for test case 5. Variation of transverse compressive strength σ2 with σ3 (where σ1 = σ3) for a unidirctional glass/epoxy. Figure 12.
Recommended scales for plotting the theoretical prediction for test case 6. Variation of the longitudinal strength σ1 with through-thickness stress (σ3 = σ2) for a unidirectional glass/epoxy. Figure 13.
Recommended scales for plotting the theoretical prediction for test case 7. Variation of the longitudinal strength σ1 with through-thickness stress (σ3 = σ2) for a UD Carbon/epoxy. Figure 14.
Recommended scales for plotting the theoretical prediction for test case 8. Variation of axial compressive strength σy with through-thickness stress σz for (+35°/−35°)s glass/epoxy laminate, where σx = σz).14. Figure 15.
Recommended scales for plotting the theoretical prediction for test case 9. Axial compressive stress–strain curves for (+35°/−35°)s glass/epoxy laminate under σx = σz = −100 MPa.15. Figure 16.
Recommended scales for plotting the theoretical prediction for test case 10. Variation of the through-thickness shear (τzy) versus through-thickness stress (σz) for (+45°/−45°/90°/0°)s carbon/epoxy laminate. Figure 17.
Recommended scales for plotting the theoretical prediction for test case 11. Variation of the through-thickness shear (τzy) versus through-thickness stress (σz) for (0°/90°)s carbon/epoxy laminate. Figure 18.
Recommended scales for plotting the theoretical prediction for test case 12. Compressive through-thickness stress–strain curves for (0°/90°)s carbon/epoxy laminate.

Schematic diagrams showing the loading directions, layer and laminate dimensions and stacking sequence of the laminates are shown in Figures 7 to 18. Note that the angles of the fibres in each layer are measured from x direction as shown in Figure 2. In addition to details of the loading configurations, Figures 7 to 18 show also the scales of the graphs the organisers have supplied to all of the participants to follow, in order to facilitate comparison between the various predictions. In those situations where the predicted curves fall outside of the scales that were provided, the contributors were advised to use scales that suited their predictions.

sec.title: Selection of test cases
sec.p:
It is recognised that there are many interesting and unresolved problems in the area of predicting the stress–strain characteristics and fracture of composite laminates under triaxial stresses. Hence, selecting the laminates and loading conditions to be analysed was not easy. The following factors were taken into consideration:
The problems should cover a wide range of lay-ups, starting from an isotropic material to lamina and then to a laminate. For this reason, five different lay-ups were chosen and these are a polymeric material, (0°), (0°/±45°/90°)s, (±35°)s and (0°/90°)s.
The test cases should include laminates that are of practical use. For this matter, laminates used in aircrafts (e.g. (0°/±45°/90°)s), pressure vessels (e.g. (±35°)s), struts and space were included in the exercise.
A wide range of loading conditions should be analysed. The cases selected included generating the complete failure envelopes under combined stresses (σx, σy and σz), (σx, σy, σz and τxy) (σz versus τzy) and pure through-thickness (σz) loading.
The problems should include predicting the stress–strain curves under both uniaxial and triaxial loading because changes in laminate stiffness may be critical in some applications.
The laminates analysed should be capable of developing different types of damage due to loading in shear, tension and compression, transverse and parallel to the fibre direction.
Both linear and nonlinear behaviour of unidirectional laminae should be considered.
Experimental results should be available which could be used to check the effectiveness of the theoretical predictions.

Test case 1 is aimed at assessing how the composite failure theories predict the compressive strength of an isotropic polymer material in the presence of hydrostatic pressure compression. This represents the simplest form of triaxial failure of isotropic materials.

Test cases 2 to 4 are dealing with studying how large hydrostatic pressure affect the shear strength, ultimate shear failure strain and the shape of the shear stress–strain curve behaviours of a carbon/epoxy unidirectional lamina.

Test cases 5 to 7 are concerned with assessing the enhancement (or reduction) in the transverse or longitudinal strengths of a unidirectional lamina with the presence of stresses in the perpendicular directions. In test case 5, the lamina is subjected to a stress in the transverse direction (σ2) and an equal stress component in the fibre and through-thickness directions (σ1 = σ3).

However, in test cases 6 and 7, the laminae are subjected to a stress in the fibre (longitudinal) direction (σ1) and an equal stress component in the transverse and through-thickness directions (σ2 = σ3). The difference between these two cases is that one of them (test case 6) deals with isotropic fibres and the other (Test Case 7) deals with anisotropic fibres. For these cases, even in the absence of no longitudinal stress component (σ1 = 0), the solution of these cases provide information on the failure of a unidirectional under equi-biaxial stresses (σ2 = σ3) in the transverse and through-thickness directions.
Test cases 8 to 12 look into the behaviour of multi-directional laminates under stresses containing one in the through-thickness direction.

Test cases 1, 5 and 8 (and 9) are important in a number of aspects and can provide lessons on a number of fundamental issues. In order to assess how the current theories deal with the prediction of isotropic and anisotropic materials, two test cases were set up and these are test case 1 and test case 5. Test case 1 deals with an isotropic material subjected to a range of triaxial compressive stress states and test case 5 is concerned with a unidirectional laminate subjected to the same conditions. Note that the epoxy (MY750) exhibits isotropic stiffness and its uniaxial tensile strength is lower than the uniaxial compressive strength. The E-glass/MY750 UD lamina in test case 5 exhibited large strength values in the fibre direction and low values in the transverse direction (Tables 1 and 3).

The two cases (1 and 5) are interrelated insofar as the epoxy polymer material studied in case 1 is the same resin matrix used in making the E-glass/epoxy composite laminate in test case 5. Hence, in choosing test cases 1 and 5 these will begin to illuminate the assumptions made in each theory regarding the treatment of material isotropy/anisotropy and material heterogeneity.

Test cases (1 and 5) selected here are important building blocks in our understanding of traditional, high performance, continuous fibre, laminated composites which typically contain 60% fibre volume fraction in order to gain both stiffness and strength. It is accepted that a number of failure models rely on micro-mechanics to model the behaviour of the composite starting from that of the constituents, namely fibres and matrix. For this reason, a full understanding of the response of resin matrix is crucial for gaining an insight into how these micro-mechanics models tackle the behaviour of one of the main constituents of a composite material.

Test case 8 is related to the prediction of a multi-directional laminate made of the same plies as those used in test case 1 and test case 5. However, the fibre directions are oriented at −35° and +35° relative to the x direction. The laminate is subjected to various triaxial loadings, including hydrostatic pressure similar to that encountered in test cases 1 and 5. Hence, a study of this laminate would provide an insight into how changing fibre orientation and lamination could affect the strength and deformation under 3D stress loadings.

list-item.p: This article has presented the full input data provided to all the 12 participants taking part in the WWFE-II.

The article described the 12 test cases that were set-up to challenge the models employed by the participants. This included the five laminates, five materials, nine loading conditions and the forms for presenting the predictions. Nine failure envelopes and three stress–strain curves were also described.
All the guidelines issued to the participants were also listed in the article.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was partially funded by the Royal Society in the United Kingdom.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors would like to thank the UK Royal Society for awarding Dr Kaddour the Royal Society Industry Fellowship. We also thank Prof PA Smith (The University of Surrey) and Dr Shuguang Li (Nottingham University) for the supports and the technical advice throughout the period of running the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.

sec.title: Instructions to contributors
sec.p:
The following provides general guidelines and instructions that you may find helpful when writing your paper and making your submission.
The in-plane loads (section stresses) should be applied in the x and y directions defined in the diagrams provided for each laminate.
The through-thickness stresses should be applied in the z direction.
The section stresses σx and σy are defined in the usual way as the in-plane loads per unit width divided by the total thickness of the laminate.
Unless otherwise stated, please assume that the loads are increased monotonically, keeping any combination of the following ratios σx/σy/σz/τxy/τxz/τyz constant. (For test cases 4 and 9, please refer to the notes below Table 9.)
Please, record and tabulate the magnitude of the stresses (and if appropriate the type and location of failure as well as the mode of failure) at which each failure is predicted.
Repeat the calculation to cover the range of stress ratios (2 or 4 quadrants) indicated by the graphs provided for each laminate.
If possible, please plot the results using the scales provided for each laminate.
Draw curves through the results to represent the initial (inner), and final (outer) failure envelopes. Indicate any intermediate failure points/curves. Figure 6 shows a schematic of a failure envelope representing various stages of failure. The aim of this figure is to illustrate what a failure envelope is. It is possible that not all the envelopes will be closed and, in this case, please indicate the stress ratios and stress regime where the envelope is open.
For the stress–strain curves, please plot the section stress versus strain curves as requested for particular laminates using the scales provided.
It would be extremely helpful if you would also send us your tables of results, but these will probably not be included in the paper. Results in the form of data files sent to us by E-mail or other accessible forms (e.g. CD) would be appreciated.
We are asking all of the contributors to use the same material properties even if you have reservations about the values provided.
Your theory may not require all the lamina properties provided (e.g. some models and computer programs assume linear elastic properties). In that case please employ your usual assumptions and neglect any information which is not needed.
If your theory requires additional (or different) information from that provided, please let us know as soon as possible and we will endeavour to provide that information. If you have default values for any missing parameters (e.g. interaction coefficients), we prefer you to use those.
In some cases the theory employed may not be intended to be applied to the whole range of laminates specified here. In that case, you may opt to analyse only some of the laminates but please explain the reasons for not analysing the other laminates in your paper.
The paper should describe your failure theory and method of application to laminates in sufficient detail to allow your predictions to be reproduced by others, comment on the nature and the effects of the failures predicted and, if appropriate, how your predictions could be used for design.

After receiving all the theoretical papers for publications, the experimental results will be superimposed on the theoretical predictions. The superimposed graphs will be sent back to you together with tables of the experimental results for your future use and information on how the experimental results were obtained.

The second paper (Part B) would present graphs of superimposed results with any comment you may wish to make on the correlation between experiment and theory. You may choose to add a figure (or figures) and appropriate sections to demonstrate refinement or particular features of your approach. You could indicate any future development to your theory which would allow you to consider a wider variety of laminates than those you are able to analyse immediately.

For those participants who have integrated failure analyses and structural analysis packages, details of the specimen geometries that you may opt to analyse as part of the second paper, will be sent as soon as you request them.

Further clarifications, instructions and guidelines to the participants of WWFE-II
We recommend that, for the sake of completing Part A submission, all the participants consider no edge effects on the failure of the laminates. For those models that are capable of analysing the influence of edge effects on failure, details of specimen’s geometry and shapes would be provided in Part B of the exercise.
Please assume that the specimen’s dimensions are large enough so that the ‘gauge length’ is much larger than the ‘decay length’.
For the laminates in test cases 8 to 12, the organisers have deliberately not specified the number of plies because we were not certain whether the available models could cope with dealing with changing the number of plies, say from 4 to 50 or 100 plies. Having a large number of plies could undermine the computational capabilities of some of the models and hence we have refrained from suggesting the number of plies that should be analysed. If, however, your model takes into account the effect of thickness and the number of plies on the failure predictions, please consider the following points:
All the laminates are balanced and symmetric.
All the plies have the same thickness.
Please provide predictions describing the effect of thickness and number of plies on the failure of the laminates. The thickness could vary from 2 to 30 mm.
As for the values of the fracture toughness, please use the following values for your Part (A) paper.
As for the mixed mode toughness, please employ your best curve you are familiar with.
The stresses in Figures 23 and 24 should have read τyz rather than τyz.
The schematic in Figure 23 should be that of a (0°/90°/+45°/−45°)s laminate.
For those models capable of considering the effects of thermal stresses, we recommend the analysis be carried out for two cases (a) with thermal stresses and (b) with no thermal stresses.
Guidelines for the curing cycles are as follows:
For E-glass/MY750 laminates:

2 h at 90°C, 1.5 h at 130°C and then 2 h at 150°C with maximum rate of change of 1°C/min.
For IM7/8551:

1 h at 107°C followed by 2 h at 177°C.
MaterialGIC (J/m2)GIIC (J/m2)
IM7/8551-7 200 610
E-glass/epoxy 240 1500
